awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Mentoring Consortium at the Twentieth International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports student travel for select students participating in the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium (DMC) at the Twentieth International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems (AAMAS 2021) will be held in London, England, May 3-7, 2021.  This is the premier international conference for researchers in agents and multi-agent systems (MAS) across a fully international research community.  This consortium is oriented on research and career development for students who have identified their PhD topics and are just embarking on that independent research. The central activities for the DMC include opportunities for students to present and discuss their work with their peers; interaction with an identified group of senior researchers for advice on Ph.D. research, a career panel to discuss career choices in industry and academia, small group activities led by assigned mentors, and a great deal of opportunity for interactions with the international research community in AAMAS, which might lead to future collaborative activity. In addition, the DMC includes a tutorial program with full-day and half-day tutorials that will provide detailed overviews of specific subfields by leading researchers in the field. 

Sponsoring student travel to AAMAS conveys many benefits beyond the DMC program. The sponsored students have full access to a well-developed AAMAS workshop and conference program covering a diverse range of research areas in this community. This is an opportunity for students to engage in discussion with scientists from around the world and to explore new research directions and topics. AAMAS is the major international conference that will figure prominently in the research careers of students who remain involved in agents and MAS. Students gain valuable research insights from the exchange of technical ideas in this broader venue. In the process, they make valuable connections with potential collaborators from around the world. As intelligent software and embodies systems become more prevalent, it is clear that advances in intelligent agent technology will have significant impact in virtually any domain imaginable, including such national priorities as health and well-being, e-commerce, and national defense.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
MAJOR GOALS and ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE PROJECT

The initial goal of this project is to partially support the travel of US doctoral students to the premier International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) and their participation in the Doctoral Consortium (DC) held in conjunction with it. 

Because AAMAS 2021 was a fully virtual conference (due to COVID-19) on May 3-7, 2021, the project fund is used to support conference attendance and paper registration fees of the students (when applicable). 

Under the NSF-approved no-cost extension, the remaining fund was used to support conference attendance and paper registration fees of the students (when applicable) attending AAMAS 2022, which was held virtually on May 9-13, 2022. 

MAJOR ACTIVITIES

AAMAS is the premier conference devoted to all aspects of research and application of agent and multiagent systems technology, a key area of research with applications to the success of internet technologies, electronic commerce, digital libraries, robotics, personal agents, and virtual humans. Students awarded funding (virtually) participated in a Doctoral Consortium in which they discussed their research with other student researchers and received feedback from a group of senior researchers. Students also (virtually) attended the conference, which had a rich technical program complemented by an array of workshops, tutorials, and other events. 

Because AAMAS-21 was a virtual conference, all students delivered live virtual presentations over zoom to describe their work. Students all logged in during the 2-day Doctoral Consortium program, approximately 6-hour slots each day, to allow interaction and group advising. 

The 2­-day consortium included:

1)    Technical sessions in which students presented their work.

  1. An introduction session where each student briefly described their own research (i.e., elevator pitches).
  2. A more formal presentation session where each student presents their own research (i.e., 15-min presentations). 

2)    A group breakout session where students formed groups and participated in a group ideation competition on how to address societal problems using their research. 

3)    An invited talk on AI for Social Good was given by Milind Tambe (Professor at Harvard University). 

4)    A career advice panel was given by Maria Gini (Professor at University of Minnesota), Tathagata Chakraborti (a researcher at IBM Research), Vincent Conitzer (Professor at Carnegie Mellon University), and Fei Fang (Assistant Professor at Carnegie Mellon University). 

84 graduate and undergraduate students received support (in the form of conference attendance or paper registrations), out of which 22 were women.  

In the AAMAS-22 (virtual) edition of the Doctoral Consortium program, all students delivered live virtual presentations over zoom to describe their work. Students all logged in during the 1-day Doctoral Consortium program, approximately 11-hour slot, to allow interaction and group advising. 

The 1-day consortium included:

1)    Technical sessions in which students presented their work.

  1. An introduction session where each student briefly described their own research (i.e., elevator pitches).
  2. A more formal presentation session where each student presents their own research (i.e., 15-min presentations). 

2)    An invited talk on Responsible AI was given by Virginia Dignum (Professor at Umeå University). 

3)    A career advice panel was given by Maria Gini (University of Minnesota), Sandip Sen (University of Tulsa), Peter Stone (University of Texas at Austin), and Manuela Veloso (Carnegie Mellon University)

73 graduate and undergraduate students received support (in the form of conference attendance or paper registrations), out of which 15 were women.  

Participation in the doctoral consortium and the conference provided motivation and excitement for students to continue in their research journey. It also helped them become members of the international community of scholars, by making personal connections with other researchers from around the world and by increasing their awareness of how progress in science can benefit all countries. Student scholarship funds make it possible for groups to send multiple students to attend the same conference, rather than simply having all conference papers presented by a senior researcher. In particular, due to the virtual conference and lower costs, we were able to fund a large number of students. As a result, we were able to greatly increase the participation of students. 

Scholarships were chosen on the basis of:

1) Match between their research topic and the topics covered in the DC;
2) Level of participation in the AAMAS conference;
3) Diversity of the participants;
5) Time to anticipated graduation

 


Last Modified: 01/09/2023
Modified by: Hau Chan
